notesStmt.note: Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: Pentateuch (aka the 'Almanzi Pentateuch') with Hafṭarot and Five Scrolls.

collation.p: 60 quires: i10 (folios 1-10), ii-xii8 (folios 11-98), xiii6 (folios 99-104), xiv-xv8 (folios 105-120), xvi6 (folios 121-126), xvii4 (folios 127-130), xviii-xxxv8 (folios 131-274), xxxvi6 (folios 275-280), xxxvii-xlii8 (folios 281-328), xliii6 (folios 329-334), xliv-lix8 (folios 335-462), lx2 (folios 463-464). Catchwords at the end of the quires, probably added later.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Sefardi square script, third quarter of 15th century, punctuated.

decoDesc.decoNote: 11v 5 frontispieces with initial-word panels and full floral border, in colours and gold.
86r 5 frontispieces with initial-word panels and full floral border, in colours and gold.
149v 5 frontispieces with initial-word panels and full floral border, in colours and gold.
192v 5 frontispieces with initial-word panels and full floral border, in colours and gold.
256r 5 frontispieces with initial-word panels and full floral border, in colours and gold.
1v-8v30 masoretic lists decorated with penwork and full pen-flourished border, in mauve ink.
455r-462r30 masoretic lists decorated with penwork and full pen-flourished border, in mauve ink.
Numerous parashah signs decorated with pen-flourishing, in mauve, blue and red ink.
Numerous initial-word panels with penwork and pen-flourishing, in mauve and black ink.

binding.p: Post-1660. Dark green leather binding, tooled in gold, centrepiece. Spine: 'The Pentateuch, Hafṭaroth, and Five Megilloth. Hebrew. Brit. Mus. Additional 27, 167.'

history.provenance: Acquisition: Giuseppe Almanzi (b. 1801, d. 1860), Italian bibliophile: his manuscript no. 277 (folio [465r]); his library including 322 medieval Hebrew manuscripts were purchased en bloc by the British Museum in October 1865 for £1,000 through Asher & Co., Berlin dealer to the British Museum (see 131-153): inscribed (folio [465r]).
